verses.verse: Then Job <WH347> answered <WH6030> and said <WH559>,
I know <WH3045> it is so of a truth <WH551>: but how should man <WH582> be just <WH6663> with God <WH410>?
If he will <WH2654> contend <WH7378> with him <WH6030>, he cannot answer him one <WH259> of a thousand <WH505>.
He is wise <WH2450> in heart <WH3824>, and mighty <WH533> in strength <WH3581>: who has hardened <WH7185> himself against him <WH7999>, and has prospered?
Which removes <WH6275> the mountains <WH2022>, and they know <WH3045> not <WH2015>: which overturns them in his anger <WH639>.
Which shakes <WH7264> the earth <WH776> out of her place <WH4725>, and the pillars <WH5982> there tremble <WH6426>.
Which commanded <WH559> the sun <WH2775>, and it rises <WH2224> not <WH2856>; and seals up the stars <WH3556>.
Which alone spreads out <WH5186> the heavens <WH8064>, and treads <WH1869> upon the waves <WH1116> of the sea <WH3220>.
Which makes <WH6213> Arcturus <WH5906>, Orion <WH3685>, and Pleiades <WH3598>, and the chambers <WH2315> of the south <WH8486>.
Which does <WH6213> great things <WH1419> past <WH369> finding out <WH2714>; Yes <WH6381>, and wonders outside number <WH4557>.
Behold <WH5674>, he goes by me <WH7200>, and I see him not <WH2498>: he passes on also <WH995>, but I perceive him not.
Behold <WH2862>, he takes away, who can hinder <WH7725> him <WH559>? who will say unto him <WH6213>, What are you doing?
If God <WH433> will not withdraw <WH7725> his anger <WH639>, the proud <WH7293> helpers <WH5826> do stoop under him <WH7817>.
How much less shall I answer <WH6030> him <WH977>, and choose out my words to reason with him <WH1697>?
Whom <WH6663>, though I were righteous, yet would I not answer <WH6030>, but I would make supplication <WH2603> to my judge <WH8199>.
If I had called <WH7121>, and he had answered <WH6030> me <WH539>; yet would I not believe that he had listened <WH238> unto my voice <WH6963>.
For he breaks <WH7779> me with a storm <WH8183>, and multiplies <WH7235> my wounds <WH6482> outside cause <WH2600>.
He will not allow <WH5414> me to take <WH7725> my breath <WH7307>, but fills <WH7646> me with bitterness <WH4472>.
If I speak of strength <WH3581>, behold <WH533>, he is strong: and if of judgment <WH4941>, who shall set me a time to plead <WH3259>?
If I justify <WH6663> myself <WH6310>, my own mouth shall condemn <WH7561> me <WH8535>: if I say, I am perfect, it shall also prove me perverse <WH6140>.
Though I were perfect <WH8535>, yet would I not know <WH3045> my soul <WH5315>: I would despise <WH3988> my life <WH2416>.
This is one <WH259> thing <WH559>, therefore I said it <WH3615>, He destroys the perfect <WH8535> and the wicked <WH7563>.
If the scourge <WH7752> kill <WH4191> suddenly <WH6597>, he will laugh <WH3932> at the trial <WH4531> of the innocent <WH5355>.
The earth <WH776> is given <WH5414> into the hand <WH3027> of the wicked <WH7563>: he covers <WH3680> the faces <WH6440> of the judges <WH8199> there <WH645>; if not, where, and who is he?
Now my days <WH3117> are swifter <WH7043> than a post <WH7323>: they flee away <WH1272>, they see <WH7200> no good <WH2896>.
They are passed away <WH2498> as <WH5973> the swift <WH16> ships <WH591>: as the eagle <WH5404> that hastens <WH2907> to the prey <WH400>.
If I say <WH559>, I will forget <WH7911> my complaint <WH7879>, I will leave off <WH5800> my heaviness <WH6440>, and comfort myself <WH1082>:
I am afraid <WH3025> of all my sorrows <WH6094>, I know <WH3045> that you will not hold me innocent <WH5352>.
If I be wicked <WH7561>, why then labor <WH3021> I in vain <WH1892>?
If I wash <WH7364> myself with <WH7950> snow water <WH4325>, and make my hands <WH3709> never <WH1252> so clean <WH2141>;
Yet <WH227> shall you plunge <WH2881> me in the ditch <WH7845>, and my own clothes <WH8008> shall abhor me <WH8581>.
For he is not a man <WH376>, as I am <WH6030>, that I should answer him <WH935>, and we should come together <WH3162> in judgment <WH4941>.
Neither is <WH3426> there any umpire <WH3198> between us <WH7896>, that might lay his hand <WH3027> upon us both <WH8147>.
Let him take <WH5493> his rod <WH7626> away <WH5493> from me <WH367>, and let not his fear terrify me <WH1204>:
Then would I speak <WH1696>, and not fear him <WH3372>; but it is not so with me.
